page.title: 12EGGS IN THE ARRETON VALLEY
page.content: R.E. and J.E. Richards own a 31 and a half acre farm at Winford Cross. Much of the land is used for cereal crops but egg production is their main income. Beginning in 1966 with less than 500 hens the farm has been developed to house 15,750. They are bought into the farm as sixteen to eighteen week old pullets and are kept for one year. All the hens are Ross Brown Hybrids and are kept in cages of 3 to a cage in the battery system. At one year old the hens are considered to be past their most efficient laying period. They are sold to mainland companies which process the meat into pastes, sausages, chicken roll etc. The bones are used for fertiliser and the feathers for the stuffing in pillows _ nothing is wasted.
